How did you communicate with one another when you were campaigning?
Well, I suppose that's one of the things that's very different from between 1970, 1980 and now.
In the 70s and 80s, as I say, I remember meeting in Charles Street with the Women's Action Group
and then after that in the Women's Centre in Cotais, which I think was a place that we...
Oh no, at one point, sorry, just forgotten.
I think we met upstairs at 108 Bookshop.
We certainly used 108 Bookshop, which was also in Cotais, as a postal address
because some of the leaflets that we produced gave that as a postal address.
And then maybe after 108 closed, we used the Women's Centre.
The thing we didn't have, of course, was only digital media, so communications were slower.
You did actually have to meet in person, apart from making telephone calls,
but as a group you had to meet in person.
And the national conferences were very important because they were the only way, really,
of having discussions with women outside your immediate geographical area.
And we also had newsletters that came out from the national abortion campaign
and we produced leaflets for distribution locally.
We also, at one point, had a video that we took round to show different groups,
but although we found a reference to the video in the minutes,
none of us can remember what the video actually was, which is a bit of a shame,
I've got the suspicion that it wasn't one that was made about us or by us,
but would be one that we had bought a copy of so that we could take it round,
but we haven't. I really don't remember.
Looking back, what sort of difference do you think your campaigning made?
Well, I think we've been successful.
I mean, not in the sense that we've succeeded in extending abortion rights to women in Northern Ireland,
not in the sense that we have succeeded in decriminalising abortion.
Women still have to get the approval of two doctors in order to have an abortion,
which many people these days agree is unnecessary.
It's not something that would be the case for any other medical or surgical procedure,
unless you wanted a second opinion. So it's archaic.
And we did defend the 1967 Act from being substantially altered,
with the exception of the reduction of the time limit from 28 to 24 weeks,
which was done, I think I'm right in saying, in the 1990s,
at the point where people recognised that medical science had developed since 1967
and that pre-term babies could survive from a much younger gestational age than previously,
whether they survived in great numbers or whether they survived with a good quality of life,
there's another question, but the fact is that babies born at 26 weeks can sometimes survive these days.
Felly, rwy'n credu bod ni wedi'i wneud yn dda iawn,
a rwy'n credu bod y ffaith bod yn dda, 80%, y 80% o'r cyfleoedd yn supportu rhan o ddod o ddod o bortio,
yw oherwydd bod ffeministau fel fi wedi'i ddod yn dda, ar ddod o blynyddoedd,
yn ystod y peth pan nid oedd yn dda yn dda arall.
Dwi ddim yn gallu angen beth yw'r cwestiwn wedi'i ddod, dwi'n ddweud, y peth yna yw'r gysylltiad yma wedi'i wneud?
Rwy'n credu ein bod ni wedi'i wneud y gysylltiad, nid oedd yn cael gennych.
Mae angen bethau dda yn y ddod yng nghymru, dwi'n credu bod y ddod 1861,
sy'n gwneud y gysylltiad ym mhobol, yn gweithio o ddod o bortio,
yn dda i'w ddod, ac rwy'n credu bod y ddod yma, y ddod ym mhobol,
yn dda i'w ddod o ddod y ddod ym mhobol, ar y ddod yn y ddod ym mhobol,
a rwy'n credu, yn fwy o bwynt, bod y ddod yn dda i'w ddod ym mhobol.
Yn ogystal â'r ddod, neu'r ddod yn dda i'w ddod yn ym mhobol,
os yw'r ddod yn dda i'w ddod yn dda i'r ddod ym mhobol,
y ddod 1867 arall yn ymwneud â phobl yn Iwerddon.
Rwy'n credu bod y ddod yn Iwerddon yn dda i'w ddod eich rhai
bilt clothr hydrated off by cynical political parties.
It's grotescent ly unfair
ai fod ahonyn sail i'r ystradd gyda llyfrion yma
and then the United Kingdom,
a dyna AE rhaid y gall aer ddod y ddod spoil.
ymlaen. Oherwydd, o ran ymlaen, rydym yn ffyrdd ymlaen yw'r ymgyrch ym mhob yw'n
gallu cael ymgyrch ymlaen a'r amlwg lleol i'r mwyaf o bobl sy'n eisiau un, nid i'r

gael ymlaen. Mae gennym ymlaen ymlaen i'w gael.
